threads.com:
I took in two stray cats and need names for them, though I'm a little annoyed about some information I wasn't given on the second, but I come to you asking for help deciding on names.

This is the first one. About a week ago he just started coming into my apartment like he was my cat every time I opened the door begging for food. Everyone kept saying "Well, if you're feeding him, he's your cat now." Predictably he showed up with a limp one day so I brought him in to try and treat his paw. I've been putting neosporin and hydrogen peroxide on it, but improvement has been slow. He doesn't act like he's in pain, I've examined his leg, I think it's this cut he has on one of his pawpads. If it doesn't get better before long I'm just going to take him to the vet.

Extremely docile and pliable. He'll go to sleep wherever I plop him down, very mellow, yellow fellow. Does have odd eating habits though, he likes cheeseburger hamburger helper and avocado.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This is the second one. I was shocked that other than his fur being a darker orange, he looks much the same as the one I just took in. A friend of my mother's asked if I'd be willing to take it in, I'm kind of known for nursing sick strays back to health, and I said sure. This one's been in my apartment less than an hour. He was scared at first, but maybe five minutes after being let out he's running all over the apartment and meowing. He's a kitten so, way higher energy. When my mom was on the way she said "She's sending you cat food for him." "Oh, I have cat food." "Also neosporin and antibacterial for his ears." "...What's wrong with his ears?" "Oh nothing, she just likes to make sure they're taken care of."

So, his ears are fucked. I've never dealt with a cat having whatever this is. I don't know if it's scabies, he's not missing fur anywhere else. I'm worried I could infect the other cat with it. He's a lot less docile than the cat I'd already taken in though. He likes to play fight. Also, the one I already had has no problem with others eating his food, he'll even groom them while they do it, but the kitten doesn't seem much to like him. I tried putting him on the recliner with him and the kitten growled at him and jumped away.

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

>>4364203
Don't worry, it can easily go two months without water. In fact, when growing them indoors, it's best not to treat them like (most) succulents with regards to watering, meaning don't water often, but when you do, soak them. After it's been dry for a couple of weeks/months, fill up a bowl with lukewarm water, just put your Tillandsia in there, and let it swim for a day, maybe two if it's been a long time since it last received water. After it's had a nice long bath, shake off the excess water and let it dry upside down. Repeat the process in a month or two and it'll grow just fine. Once you get the hang of it, you can (but don't have to) water more often to let it grow a bit faster, especially when it's nice and warm in the summertime. Tillandsia ionantha, like most Tillandsia, still grows very slowly, though.

Just to be sure that it's actually T. ionantha and not one of the million other species that are often mislabelled, is it pretty much identical to the one in this picture?

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

threads.com:
How do you deal with a clingy cat who has abandonment issues?

My little kitten was a stray before I took him in, I believe he was around a month old, he could (kinda) walk by himself, but he was still only eating kitten formula. He could engage in light play.
He's now around 5 months, And he's the clingiest dang cat alive. If I'm not in the room with him he meows at the top of his lungs and wants to pull up the carpet. He also zero sense of boundaries, he plays way too rough after repeated "gentle" scoldings. At first I just completely ignored him and disengaged in play, but then he tried to make an ambitious jump on the back of my chair and we had to make an emergency vet visit (he was fine, just needed a shot for swelling)
After that, I tried hissing back at him to let him know he was being too rough, I figured since he didn't grow up with siblings he never learned boundaries and that's how they would do it.
After that didn't work I started being a little rougher, I would (gently) toss him away while trying to do a combination of the previous two, but that didn't work either. Lately he's been getting on my nerves more, and since he's more grown his bites REALLY hurt even if I know he just wants to play. I accidentally scruffed him off of me the other day, and I still feel kinda bad from it.
I'm worried this might be a behavior he retains growing into adulthood, but I've never really owned a male kitten before. I'm not sure if he'll calm down after he gets neutered in a month or not.

Any help is appreciated, thanks.
Pictured is my little super model.

I wrapped it in a blanket and put it in my bathtub with a shoebox bed, bowl of water, and a granola bar because I thought it needed to just warm up or something. My bathroom is really warm, because there's a heater in there and I keep the door closed to trap the heat. I don't have any big containers/boxes or cages to keep it in so that small shoebox in the bathtub is the best I have. I tried contacting my local animal hospital and they told me it would cost me to bring someone out there since I moved it and nuts to that. I googled some sites and it said it's either in shock or pregnant, but it doesn't seem like that's the case (maybe shocked but how long can a squirrel be shocked?)

tl;dr I found a squirrel not moving, still breathing, doesn't look injured, it's eyes are whitened, it pissed itself before me opening the door,
I think it warmed up because the last time I checked up on it, it was shaking it's arms a lot.

Is it injured or is it dying?

>>4360406
I know what you mean, but these are my lab rats and they're bred in extremely strict conditions to be incredibly resistant to disease. Just wanted to clear up this misunderstanding between laboratory animals and general albino feeders, if people are interested in rescuing. Laboratory rats cost b/w $300-$2000 per rat. In labs they're housed in shoe box sized tanks with only the barred roof for ventilation. It's only cleaned once a week, but even with the immense ammonia buildup these rats never succumb to respiratory illness. Probably the only advantage of having biomedical research grade sprague dawleys. If they experienced any health issues beyond the ones being studied, it would ruin experiments, so it's ensured that these strains are highly resistant to all diseases and cancers. They are born completely mycoplasma free as well. The downsides are that they're extremely skittish, poorly socialized, have poor vision, and have had little to no enrichment for most of their lives (so they're pretty deprived).

last_replies.name: sage
last_replies.com: The "doesn't really matter that much" paper doesn't even say it doesn't matter. Honestly, people who write articles (as someone who's published - human research- but published) should have someone to act as a liaison to help fucking journalists understand research or at least critically appraise it. The second article actually establishes strong heritability for certain traits (including aggressiveness and sociability) but notes there is a fair amount of intra-breed variation. No fucking shit. But that doesn't mean an effect size of a chihaua or pit bull being 25% more likely to bite compared to a labrador retriever isn't a non-negligible effect size. Especially when other social traits (such as training, biddability, etc) are likely to ameliorate others. GSDs are also extremely likely to bite, but they are *much* easier to train compared to Pitbulls or other terrier breeds. The problem happens when even though your Jack Russell is statistically as likely (or more likely) to bite little Tina, you might get a few pucture wounds. When Rudy the Pitbull bites, you get a dead toddler.

Dogs were originally bred for personality, not appearance, with good results. Looks first breeding largely destroys the work of personality first breeding and is the sole reason breeds have inconsistent temperament. A backyard line bred dog-show type dog may be more aggressive than the real working stock "mongrel". As jobs get more specific dogs get more inbred, naturally, because with things like herding, pointing, and retrieving, you go beyond personality and into disordered wolf instincts.

Humans, too, are bred for personality first, and the result has been crime/violence declining century over century.
